description:
Rhinophrynus dorsalis, commonly known as the Mexican burrowing toad or Mexican burrowing frog, is a species of toad that belongs to the family Rhinophrynidae. This small amphibian is found in parts of Mexico and Central America, including Baja California, Sonora, Sinaloa, and Nayarit in Mexico, as well as in Guatemala and El Salvador.

Rhinophrynus dorsalis is a unique frog species that has several distinct features. It has a rounded, stocky body with short, thick limbs, which are adaptations for its burrowing lifestyle. The species has a pointed snout and large, protruding eyes that are positioned on the top of its head, allowing it to see while partially submerged in the soil. The skin of Rhinophrynus dorsalis is smooth and dry, with a distinct dorsal pattern of dark spots or blotches on a pale background.

This species is primarily nocturnal and spends most of its time burrowed in the soil, emerging at night to feed on a variety of invertebrates, such as ants, termites, and beetles. Rhinophrynus dorsalis is also known for its unique vocalization, which is described as a low-pitched, grunting or snoring sound that can be heard during the breeding season.

Rhinophrynus dorsalis is considered a species of least concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as it has a relatively wide distribution and is not currently facing significant threats to its population.
